summary:
The 314 submissions to this year's short film festival presented a diverse range of experimental and conceptual works. Approximately one-third of submissions (77) received a score of 65% or higher, ultimately resulting in 53 films selected for highlights and a further 77 films categorized as ‘maybe.’ The overall average weighted score across all reviewed films was 51.5%, indicating a generally lower level of engagement with the submitted material. Notably, a strong thematic preference was observed, with 'experimental,' 'abstract,' and 'animation' appearing most frequently among curator tags, alongside recurring interests in nature, the body, and technology-related themes. This suggests a focus on unconventional approaches and concepts within the short form. 

Several standout films achieved a perfect score of 100%, including Ahmet Mete Balyan’s '#toma*_001', the collective dance piece ‘The Mobility Scooter Dance Collective,’ and a series of evocative micro-shorts. The selections leaned heavily towards works under 15 minutes, with a considerable number categorized as ‘micro-short’ (15) and ‘animation’ (44), alongside ‘abstract’ (46) and ‘experimental’ (73) approaches. Formal tendencies included a notable interest in black and white imagery (19) and a preference for concise narratives, often centered on singular experiences or moments – exemplified by several films under 10 minutes.

Ultimately, the selected group of 77 films represents a concentrated exploration of diverse artistic approaches, prioritizing conceptual and aesthetic experimentation over traditional narrative structures. While the overall average score reflects a challenging evaluation process, the selection committee identified works demonstrating a clear commitment to innovation and pushing the boundaries of the short film format. The overall runtime of the highlighted and selected films totals 913 minutes, highlighting a significant investment in these conceptual works.

highlights.title: The Mobility Scooter Dance Collective (The First Dance)

flags.label: AI
flags.details: prayertothequeenmother is a multimedia project that explores techno-economic acceleration as a process of increasingly radical abstraction of territory, the body, and the psyche. 'the garden' is a module of this project in the form of an installation, based on the sonification of global gross domestic product data and video synthesis through diffusion models. Recorded images where put through a AI image generator. This use of generative technology is not incidental. It follows an exploration of the concept of artificiality versus nature.

highlights.title: Troscurpos: From the Crown to the Wind

flags.label: AI
flags.details: Yes, AI was used to create the images of the oil extraction machines, representing how I imagine that territory from a distance. These AI-generated images were subsequently digitally manipulated through color grading, and integrated with video and VFX to construct the final poetic composition.

flags.details:
This video contains disturbing and emotionally intense imagery related to historical violence and human suffering.
There is no nudity, no sexual content, no strong language, and no epilepsy-triggering effects.
Blood/violence is implied rather than graphically shown, but the themes may be upsetting for young audiences.

selected.title: States of matter | Matters of the State

flags.label: AI
flags.details: Inputting scans of found ecological matter from the River into AI video programs, working with AI as my consultant. This process becomes an ignition point for spatial, relational and atmospheric intel that I wouldn’t have been able to generate without it; the AI is not the final thing simulation, it is a tool I use as an ignition point.

flags.label: AI

selected.title: A prompt for automactically unfolding space

flags.label: AI
flags.details:
AI-assisted image creation was used for the visual depiction of the liminal spaces shown in the bottom right part of the video.
AI-assisted voice creation was used for the auditory narration of those spaces, based on excerpts from JG Ballard's book "High-rise".
